qas.question: What's the medical term for TB when it spreads from the lungs to other parts of the body?
At least what percentage of HIV-positive patients who contract TB will experience extrapulmonary infection?
Along with people with diminished immune function, like HIV patients, what group of people is more likely to develop extrapulmonary TB?
If TB infection spreads to the central nervous system, what is it called?
What's the other name for "disseminated tuberculosis"?
What percentage of young children get Extrapulmonary TB?
What does a tuberculous ulcer result in?
What does disseminated tuberculosis look like?
What is another name for osseous tuberculosis?
What percentage of HIV positive cases also get Military TB?

context: In <b5_0>15–20%<b5_0/> of active cases, the infection spreads outside the lungs, causing other kinds of TB. These are collectively denoted as "<a0_0>extrapulmonary tuberculosis<a0_0/>". Extrapulmonary TB occurs more commonly in immunosuppressed persons and <a2_0>young children<a2_0/>. In those with HIV, this occurs in more than <a1_0>50%<a1_0/> of cases. Notable extrapulmonary infection sites include the pleura (in tuberculous pleurisy), the central nervous system (in <a3_0>tuberculous meningitis<a3_0/>), the lymphatic system (in scrofula of the neck), the genitourinary system (in urogenital tuberculosis), and the bones and joints (in Pott disease of the spine), among others. When it spreads to the bones, it is also known as "osseous tuberculosis", a form of <b8_0>osteomyelitis<b8_0/>. Sometimes, bursting of <b6_0>a tubercular abscess through skin<b6_0/> results in tuberculous ulcer. An ulcer originating from nearby infected lymph nodes is painless, slowly enlarging and has an appearance of "<b7_0>wash leather<b7_0/>". A potentially more serious, widespread form of TB is called "disseminated tuberculosis", also known as <a4_0>miliary tuberculosis<a4_0/>. Miliary TB makes up about <b9_0>10%<b9_0/> of extrapulmonary cases.
